cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels are resistant to oxidation due to their alloy content.
Stainless steels are resistant to sulfidation due to their alloy content.
Stainless steels resist various forms of general corrosion, beyond just oxidation and sulfidation, depending on alloy content.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Scope: other forms of corrosion beyond oxidation and sulfidation

remarks: Relation generalized from phrase 'other forms of corrosion' to entity 'general corrosion'.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium, as an alloying element in stainless steels, contributes to resistance against oxidation.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Context: chromium in stainless steel alloy matrix

remarks: Resistance is mediated via stainless steels; not direct chromium surface behavior, but captured as a causal contribution.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium, as an alloying element in stainless steels, contributes to resistance against sulfidation.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Context: chromium in stainless steel alloy matrix

remarks: Again, resistance is via its role in stainless steels rather than isolated chromium behavior.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium contributes to resistance to general corrosion forms when used as an alloying element in stainless steels.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels; depending on the alloy content
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Scope: general corrosion (other forms of corrosion)

remarks: Relation created mainly to capture that chromium helps overall corrosion resistance; semantics slightly generalized.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Adding approximately 0.7% chromium to low alloy C-Mo steels eliminates graphitization.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: addition of about 0.7% chromium; steels with up to 1% Mo

remarks: Material context (low alloy C-Mo steels with up to 1% Mo) added as qualifiers rather than as extra entities.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject material exhibits resistance to the specified corrosion or degradation mechanism under certain conditions.
args.justification: All three relations link stainless steel to specific or generalized corrosion mechanisms and describe the material's resistance to those mechanisms, differing only in the corrosion type (oxidation, sulfidation, general corrosion). They share the same predicate semantics: the material resists the mechanism.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject (typically an alloying element or component) causally contributes to the resistance of a material system against a specified corrosion or degradation mechanism.
args.justification: These three relations consistently describe chromium, as an alloying element in stainless steels, causally contributing to resistance against oxidation, sulfidation, or general corrosion. The subject is not the resisting bulk material but the element that provides resistance, so a causal resistance predicate distinct from plain 'resists' is appropriate.
args.remark: Context that chromium acts via stainless steel is already captured in qualifiers and does not change the predicate direction.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject inhibits or effectively eliminates the occurrence of the specified degradation or metallurgical process under the stated conditions.
args.justification: This relation describes chromium addition eliminating (inhibiting) graphitization in low alloy C-Mo steels. The semantics are direct prevention of a degradation process rather than generic resistance, so a predicate 'prevents' accurately captures the inhibitory effect.

All relations connect materials or alloying elements to corrosion or degradation mechanisms (oxidation, sulfidation, general corrosion, graphitization) and describe resistance or prevention. Despite different surface predicates ('resists', 'provides_resistance_to', 'prevents'), they share the same conceptual class: the subject mitigates or inhibits a degradation mechanism.

Each relation expresses a causal influence of a material or alloying element on the occurrence or severity of a degradation mechanism: materials resisting mechanisms and alloying elements providing resistance or preventing processes. This is best captured under a causal relation group rather than mere association.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Subject material exhibits resistance to the specified corrosion or degradation mechanism under certain conditions.

They share the same predicate semantics: the material resists the mechanism.
